name: W. Edwards Deming
background: W. Edwards Deming (1900-1993) was an American engineer, statistician, professor, author, and management consultant. Educated in electrical engineering (BS University of Wyoming), mathematical physics (MS University of Colorado, PhD Yale), he pioneered statistical quality control. Post-WWII, he transformed Japanese industry through lectures on statistical methods and management philosophy, earning the Order of the Sacred Treasure (1960) and inspiring the Deming Prize. In the US, his 1980 NBC documentary 'If Japan Can... Why Can't We?' sparked recognition. Key works: 'Out of the Crisis' (1982, 14 Points), 'The New Economics' (1993, System of Profound Knowledge). He emphasized 85% of problems stem from systems/management, not workers. Deming advocated PDCA/PDSA for continuous improvement, influencing Total Quality Management (TQM), Lean, and Six Sigma. Late career included consulting (e.g., Ford's turnaround) and founding the Deming Institute.

principles.name: 14 Points for Management
principles.description: 14 obligations for transforming management: e.g., 'Create constancy of purpose'; 'Cease dependence on inspection'; 'Drive out fear'; 'Improve constantly'; full list in 'Out of the Crisis'. Direct quote: 'Adopt the new philosophy... Western management must awaken to the challenge.' (deming.org)

principles.description: Replace fear/blame with trust; understand human motivation. Point 8: 'Drive out fear, so that everyone may work effectively.' Part of SoPK psychology.
